articles.description: Law enforcement and other officials say an aircraft went down near Ronald Reagan National Airport, and all takeoffs and landings have been halted. Multiple helicopters, including those from the U.S. Park Police and the D.C. Metropolitan Police Department and U.S. military, were flying over the scene of the incident in the Potomac River on Wednesday night. D.C. Fire and EMS said on X that fireboats were on the scene. The airport said emergency personnel were responding to “an aircraft incident on the airfield.” Video from an observation camera at the nearby Kennedy Center shows two sets of lights consistent with aircraft appearing to conjoin in a fireball.
articles.title: Aircraft down near Washington's Reagan Airport; takeoffs and landings halted

articles.author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
articles.description: A passenger jet has collided with a helicopter while landing at Ronald Reagan National Airport near Washington. There was no immediate word on casualties, but all takeoffs and landings from the airport near Washington have been halted.
articles.title: Live updates: A passenger jet collides with helicopter while landing at Reagan Washington National Airport

articles.author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
articles.description: A passenger jet collided Wednesday with an Army helicopter while landing at Ronald Reagan National Airport near Washington, prompting a large search-and-rescue operation in the nearby Potomac River.
articles.title: Live updates: Passenger jet with 64 aboard collides with Army helicopter at Reagan Airport near DC

articles.author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
articles.description: A passenger jet collided Wednesday with an Army helicopter while landing at Ronald Reagan National Airport near Washington, prompting a large search-and-rescue operation in the nearby Potomac River.
articles.title: Live updates: Passenger jet with 64 aboard collides with Army helicopter at Reagan Airport near DC

articles.description: A passenger jet collided Wednesday with an Army helicopter while landing at Ronald Reagan National Airport near Washington, prompting a large search-and-rescue operation in the nearby Potomac River.

articles.author: WAFAA SHURAFA, JOSEPH KRAUSS
articles.description: Hamas is set to free three more Israeli hostages as well as five Thai captives, and Israel is to release another 110 Palestinian prisoners. The exchange expected Thursday would be the third since the start of a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip that has held for a week and a half. The truce is aimed at winding down the deadliest and most destructive war ever fought between Israel and Hamas, whose Oct. 7, 2023, attack into Israel sparked the fighting. It has held despite a dispute earlier this week over the sequence in which the hostages were released.
articles.title: Hamas is set to free 8 more hostages and Israel will release 110 prisoners as Gaza ceasefire holds

articles.author: RUSS BYNUM
articles.description: A police investigator told the man who fatally shot Ahmaud Arbery that he wasn't being arrested in an interview roughly two hours after the killing. Jurors in Georgia watched video of the February 2020 police interview Wednesday as they began hearing evidence in the trial of former District Attorney Jackie Johnson. She's charged with hindering the police investigation into Arbery's death nearly five years ago. No arrests were made for more than two months. But Johnson's defense attorneys blame police for jumping to a faulty conclusion that Arbery was legally shot after committing a crime. The video showed shooter Travis McMichael's first police interview. An investigator tells him: “You're going home today.”
articles.title: `You're going home,' police tell Ahmaud Arbery's killer in video shown to jury

articles.author: TARA COPP
articles.description: The Defense Department intelligence agency has paused observances of Martin Luther King Jr. Day, Pride Month, Holocaust Days of Remembrance and other cultural or historical annual events in response to President Donald Trump’s ban on diversity, equity and inclusion programs in the federal workplace. The instructions were published Tuesday in a Defense Intelligence Agency memo obtained by The Associated Press and affect 11 annual events, including Black History Month, which begins Saturday, and National Hispanic Heritage Month. An official says the pause was initiated by the agency and appears not to be policy across the Defense Department. A spokesman for the DIA did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
articles.title: Pentagon agency pauses celebrations for Martin Luther King Jr. Day, Black History Month and more

articles.author: WILL WEISSERT
articles.description: President Donald Trump says he’s directing the opening of a detention center at Guantanamo Bay to hold up to 30,000 migrants who are living illegally in the United States. Trump made the announcement Wednesday right before he signed the Laken Riley Act into law as his administration’s first piece of legislation. The bipartisan measure means that people who are in the United States illegally and are accused of theft and violent crimes would have to be detained and potentially deported even before a conviction.
articles.title: Trump directing the opening of Guantanamo Bay detention center to hold migrants in US illegally

articles.author: ASSOCIATED PRESS
articles.description: President Donald Trump says he will use a detention center at Guantanamo Bay to hold tens of thousands of criminal immigrants in the U.S. illegally who can’t be sent back to their home countries. While the U.S. naval base is best known for the suspects brought in after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, it also has a separate facility used for decades to hold detained immigrants. The U.S. has leased Guantanamo from Cuba for more than a century. Cuba opposes the lease and typically rejects the nominal U.S. rent payments. Trump signed a presidential memorandum and said he'd direct federal officials to get facilities ready. Border czar Tom Homan said U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement would run the facility. Still, details of the plan weren’t immediately clear.
articles.title: What to know about base where Trump will send 'criminal aliens'
